reviewText: The MRT is newer than the overhead sky train and benefits form air conditioning on the platforms wider stations and convenience of access with escalators on almost all entry points   I travelled with my parents in their 70s and they found this aspect much better than climbing stairs into the sky train system though of course the MRT has a smaller service offering it does take you directly to the Chatuchak weekend market and other attractions such as the train night market at the Thailand Cultural Center  There are plenty of ticket machines but the touch screens are not always working efficiently and it‚Äôs easier to simply queue for the counter assistants to buy a ticket they understand and speak English well If you‚Äôre over 60 it‚Äôs worth asking for a senior‚Äôs ticket though often the staff don‚Äôt believe you look your age which is flattering at least The only downsides to the MRT are that no toilets are provided as also is the case with the sky train  and services aren‚Äôt as frequent as say in other major metropolitan areas overseas If you want to avoid the heat and enjoy usually less cramped carriages than the sky train then this is a great option Very reasonably priced

reviewTitle: Good clean and mostly on time
reviewText: Public transportation in Bangkok improves a lot for the past few years  MRT and BTS are connected in many stations  To orientate yourself well make sure you study the traffic plan ahead  If you are not so familiar with the ticket machine there is also a ticket office with staff ready to help you out

Very similar to Japanese subway Arrows on the ground where to line up to board the train Very clean and very efficient Trains every 35 mins when there At end of line stops train cleaned before passengers can board Children over 140cms tall pay as adult  Still very cheap 3 x tickets from Phetcheburi to Hua Luphang 90 Baht total
Punctual clean not overcrowded and inexpensive A very good way to move in a city where traffic jams are permanent
Bangkok's MRT is a great way to get around the system It's punctual regular clean and inexpensive The MRT has a broad  network that gets you to most of the city's main attractions

I like Bangkok MRT fast efficient& clean  It gets me right to the very spot that  I want to go Saves me time and it is a comfortable ride  I love visiting Chinatown Hua Lumphung & Sam Yan station   I even use the MRT to Chatcuchak over the weekend  It is such a breeze  Definitely a must for all tourists

Got any ideas why balloons are banned Well Il tell you In Asia balloons aren‚Äôt filled with harmful helium but with hydrogen A very flammable gas which you should not take into metros So now you know  The MRT is a very convenient form of transfer to get around Bangkok The section to Tae Poon is operational and there are some massive other extensions on its way
Does what it says on the tin Easy to use subway system Price is cheap Maps make it easy to navigate Got a little overcrowded at rush hour but to be expected

reviewTitle: this is the best way to travel around bangkok,
reviewText: its cheap and efficent  better than being stuck in traffic in a taxi you can still see the city by trainand visit the many malls
I fantastically hate UBoot's that's what it is Nothing for me but maybe commuters like it Going under water is only for my own control
The MRT can be accessed off of the Skyway system and is easy to navigate  Very clean and a great way to get to the Hua Lamphong train station via the Skyway and MRT very easily
If the BTS doesn't get you where you want to go try the MRT  underground You can't share tickets between BTS & MRT though Excellent service and option of getting around Bangkok
Good to travel around some places in bangkok but they need to find solutions for the Sukhumvit station its unbelievably long on rush hours understandable but its really really long

If ever wanting to get to some locations in Bangkok in a hurry take the MRT underground train  The train system hits many city locations and for a fraction of the price it would cost for say a taxicab  However as one might imagine if utilized during the rush hour periods it WILL be very crowded That being said it's very rapid in getting from place to place and has nice cool air conditioning  Finally if you're a "frequent flyer" (user) of this train system (haha) you can obtain a special 'M' card at the ticket booths where you'll pay a small deposit and can then top up for as much as you want whenever you want and then won't have to fiddle around with waiting in line to pay in cash or coins at the machines or maned booths and only getting a one time card for that trip That way with the special 'M' card you can hit multiple stations just by scanning the card any time without having to pay for each trip with money ANDas an additional feature (and at any time) you can turn the card in to the ticket booths to get a refund if you do not wish to use it any longer They have a small menu at the ticket booths showing the different M cards available and prices and are very inexpensive so check them out if you think you may be using MRT multiple times
The MRT is definitely an easy and fast way to get around Bangkok without worrying about the Traffic Jam
Very easy system to use  So much cheaper and efficient to get around  Quick get to Chinatown which is a must

Had to wait for the third train before could get on taxi's are cheap enough so would not use again unless you are going a long way clean and fast and cheap once you get on in fairness no worst the The London Underground during rush hour and a lot cleaner and cheaper

reviewTitle: MRT beats being stuck in traffic!
reviewText: Bangkok's MRT is very clean and efficient Most of the time it will take less time vs a taxi especially during rush hour
Using MRT is quicker than getting stuck in traffic with a taxi The trains are clean and easy to use
Some stations are same with the BTS when you get around It is cheaper than BTS as well Very clean the staff is very friendlyPrice is fair enough for solo travelers

While in Thailand sometimes the traffic and taxi fare can be too much for you So MRT is one of the best solution that connects you to few of the major tourist destinations Its cheap economical and easy to travel with A usable option while you are a visitor

Street traffic in Bangkok is notoriously horrendous MRT is a much better option It's cheap and easy No hassles Easy connection to its companion systems   BTS and the AIrport Railway Also offers ELDER CARD reduced fees to foreigners  unlike the BTS

reviewTitle: Way too crowded in peak hours, already, the MRT at peak capacity already?
reviewText: Off peak this service is fast cool and efficient But at peak times sardines in cans have more room to move than MRT patrons Also my wife often grumbles when lining up trying to buy a ticket by changing a 100 baht note the usually male person safely behind the glass doesn't deign to make the change for her but directs her across the surging crowds to join yet another queue to get the necessary coins Why Does he fill inferior by having to serve a woman This happens way too often this poor service will continue until someone takes a stand and gets rid of these smug people too lazy to change a services that we used were commendably frequent but at time 2 or 3 trains were too crowded and it was more comfortable to wait for the next Overall inexpensive and recommended
The MRT is a great way of getting around It is clean and the trains are frequent Tickets are bought at a machine which was easy to use as it offered an English language option
A cheap form of transport but you have to be sure which direction you are taking Do not expect english speaking help

It's nice that trains are on time usually There are times when I am waiting for the MRT and there's massive people there I wish they have better organizing with lines cuz people in Bangkok are soooo not disciplined and some people are just straight up selfish It's clean but it's quite packed during peak hours you should plan your travels if you want to travel during peak hours which are around 6am8am and 5pm9pm sometimes ask other people though because of this reasonI don't really take them anymore wait to long and don't want to catch flu in crowded space

I usually use MRT service for transportation It is fast and convenient There will be crowded during rush hours though However MRT is still my first choice   Bangkok MRT is very clean and wellmaintained If you have an MRT card it will be much easier

Travelled twice during my 1 week stay in Bkk I didn't have a card (I had RABBIT card for BTS) so it was less convenient But you can stand in queue and get tokens from the ticket counter Very clean and service is excellent
Use  it  if  you  need  to  get  around town  and  forget  the  taxi   that's  always  stuck  in  traffic  Easy to use Not to worry

reviewTitle: beats the traffic jam but can be improved
reviewText: Depending where you want to go you might need MRT (metro) BTS skytrain or airport railway All run on different tickets and there is often quite a bit of distance between the stations For a group of 3 and more its often cheaper to take a taxi But taxi only outside rush hours

reviewTitle: MRT from bkk airport to Sukhumvit
reviewText: Works well I‚Äôve not tried the skytrain on this run yet there was a stage where you needed to drag your bags between trains

reviewTitle: Great and efficient way to get around Bangkok
reviewText: The service is frequent fast and very reliable The stations are superb Trains spotless and cool and comfortable even if you have to stand

This is a decent way to travel in Bangkok It is clean and on time The only problem is that it has a limited reach (which is nicely complemented by the BTSskytrain) This is actually expected in BKK as most of the city is in a quite difficult geological area and digging under is not too much of an option
If your destination is on the route of MRT use it instead of Skytrain that has been not so reliable these days Unfortunately MRT route cover outer Zone of Bangkok thus less popular than Skytrain

We took it to JJ Market and it was easy to navigate Only about 42 baht each way per person It was clean but crowded You can buy tokens from an actual person Keep the token when you enter and return it when you leave There are special seats reserved for monks If you are female don‚Äôt sit next to them

Although the route coverage was not as wide as BTS taking a MRT is way more comfortable It has escalator until you reach the ground haha if you are visiting Chatucak weekend market the best way to reach the market is thru Kampheng Phet MRT station the market would be just at the door step Much easier compared with Mo Chit BTS station in my opinion

I use this train service all the time goes everywhere around Bangkok you can see all the sights if you use this and the BTS sky train as well You can pay per trip or get a rabbit Card with you can purchase from the ticket office 100Baht for card and the charge it with any amount of credit makes travel simple and lasts forever
We used the MRT from the Sukhumvit Road to the river and it was a very fast service  Efficient system once you go the hang of it

reviewTitle: Easy, clean and affordable transportation around Bangkok. No hassle, safe and very prompt.
reviewText: Easy clean and affordable transportation around Bangkok No hassle safe and very prompt I was very pleasantly surprised and will definitely prefer this method of transport over tuktuk or taxi next time I'm in Bangkok

reviewTitle: Great way to get around Bangkok
reviewText: The station was 500 meters from our hotel and we were able to use it for 90% of our transportation needs from sightseeing temples to shopping at the mall and the night market

Winding it's way under the busy Bangkok streets this is certainly the 'way to go' if your journey happens to coincide with the location of the stations It's cleanliness is unsurpassed in this city and the journey costs are very reasonable
We stayed very close to an MRT station and found this the easiest way to commute around Bangkok As well as being easier it's also cheaper than the BTS

reviewTitle: Best way to commute in Bangkok
reviewText: It's clean and quick with high frequency of trains However jammed packed at rush hour so try to avoid those hours And the underground system has cool and nice platforms so you get a respite from the Bangkok heat Certain parts of the system is however above ground

reviewTitle: great way to get around and expanding
reviewText: The underground rail system in Thailand is efficient and managed better than its above ground cousin the BTS  The areas served are very different between the two  The MRT is expanding above ground as well  It is often packed and seat space is a rarity  The only complaint would be that its underground malls next to it are closing and the platforms are deep underground which means it takes a good bit of effort to reach the platform for the elderly and handicapped

The Taipei MRT is efficient easy to navigate for travelers and English speakers clean safe and convenient I‚Äôve been on a lot of subways and metros in big cities and nothing compares This is the best I highly recommend buying a several day pass if you‚Äôre here for awhile

Easy to get around fast inexpensive safe and clean trains with simple route map to follow Rode from Sukhumvit to Chinatown and back short walk to the street food and lots of fun Staff to purchase tokens were very friendly and communicated in good English even advised times of last return train and alternative if we decided to stay later

reviewTitle: Please use it, really. It's that good =)
reviewText: It's cheap  It's convenient  It's efficient and effective  It's suitable for everyone regardless of your age or physical capabilities  By the way the staffs at the ticketing counter were definitely welltrained

first I would like to say it was as if I had travelled back 20 years ago when the Singapore new trains are starting in use it is wonderful how the thais have maintain the trains and mostly are always on time unlike Singapore which always breaks down even till date u still can hear people complaining anyway it is amazing that the trains are on time and it is best way to travel in Bangkok as the traffic congestion is terrible fascinating thai have really maintain it well  well done
The MRT is similar to the MTR in HK Except the tickets The tickets in the MRT is a circle and the tickets in HK is a circle

reviewTitle: Convinient best way to skip trafic jams
reviewText: The most convenient to skip the hazel guzzle and the huge line of jams in and out to the city supper fast easy and efficient try and special day tickets are available do except queues of few tourist to get tickets and they are mini malls also available at stations

reviewTitle: Good way to travel around Bangkok
reviewText: Apart from the BTS the MRT is another good way to travel around Bangkok city Can be crowded sometimes but I found that the crowd at BTS was even worse I prefer MRT more than BTS as it is somehow more comfortable For the tickets you can pay either by coins or bank notes (for BTS some stations only accept coins) and you can buy the MRT tickets either at the ticket counters or through the machine

reviewTitle: Convenient means of transport in Bangkok
reviewText: Very easy well organized clean and rapid also cheap and safe it is one of the means of transport anyone visiting Bangkok would use at least once

reviewTitle: As fast and efficient as you could hope for
reviewText: we recently visited BKK and used the MRT quite a lot to get around Basically the system is great  fast clean cool (such great aircon on a hot day) and costeffective We found it easy to understand where we were and how to get where we wanted to go The trips were very costeffective and the ticket system worked very well and when we did need some guidance the Information staff were great Thoroughly recommend it
The subway in Bangkok is quite good  If you travel at offpeak times it is not too crowded and very comfortable  It is also quite cheap compared to US city trains
Unfortunately the MRT has a different payment system than BTS This makes the service more expensive

reviewTitle: Better than even the sky train!
reviewText: I love the BTS (Sky Train) but like the MRT even more The terminals are cooler (temperature wise) and while busy they to be a lot less crazy during the nonpeak hours than the BTS

A great service in general and seems to be well manaeged However as with other transit sytems in Thailand little planning was applied in the setup and now there is a lack of sufficient rolling stock to carry the passengers effectively This results in extended waiting times during rush hours (which are expanding daytoday)

The trains arrived on time and were airconditioned  There was no problem accessing their maps The lines covered the main central city areas but unfortunately do not go straight to Don Mueang airport so taxis and buses had to be used

I first used the MRT Blue Line when it was opened more than 10 years ago Have used it every time I visit Bangkok  This year I took the aging MRT Blue Line (underground) and changed to the new Purple Line (above the ground) at Tao Poon Station  In June 2018 they didn't set up new ticket machines yet so to go to Purple Line I bought the ticket with the staff They are all very friendly On my way back I forgot to use the new ticket machines of Purple Line so I don't know how they look  Don't buy separate tickets just buy 1 for the station you need to reach  They have a website you can know which station you need to stop and how much
it gets you to some places but it is very limited  Very crowded and often hot  Watch your bags and know where you want to get off

reviewTitle: It's not on my usual commute route
reviewText: I take it a few times per month Never disappointed Great bargain Very clean Signage with the weird arrows not exactly pointing the right way could use a little improvement  I wish the MRT BTS and Airport Link (could simplify matters by giving all interchange (connecting) stations the same name For example why not simply call the the MRT Sukhumvit Station MRT Asok to match with BTS Asok Why not call the Airport Link Makkasan Station Airport Link Petchaburi to match with MRT Petchaburi  It would make a lot more sense

reviewTitle: Convenient and Clean way to travel in Bangkok
reviewText: Would recommend you use the MRT & BTS especially as you can avoid the traffic below Compared to other metro such as Dubai Singapore Malaysia I found the Bangkok MRT & BTS very clean and a great way to commute

reviewTitle: The most convenient transportation for me in Bangkok
reviewText: The biggest reason I prefer MRT is to avoid the hot temperature It runs faster than BTS and somehow cheaper
We used this service to reach Thailand Cultural Centre It is fast convenient and clean It is also very economical
We took a train fro Asoke to Thailand Cultural Centre Very clean fast and economical mode of travel

reviewTitle: Not as convenient as the BTS
reviewText: Long cavernous empty walks to get to the stations Buying tickets for the underground MRT always seems inconvenient  long queues for the machines and coins required to buy the ticket  so often two lines are in order one to exchange notes the other to actually buy the ticket  Candidly I prefer the above ground BTS as there are views instead of feeling slightly claustrophobic  In all however this is a thoroughly modern extremely clean travel experience for a subway especially when compared to cities like Sydney and New York  And usually quicker but not always cheaper (especially when travelling with friends) than a private taxi

Access to Hua Lampong Train Station metro line comes off the Bang Wa BTS line  You have to make your way to BTS Sala Daeng and exit the BTS system  The walk is about 10 mins and signage is not obvious to the MRT  Just ask but don't let anyone ask you if they can help they will try and get you you to go somewhere else  Simply say NYET  Then they know you don't speak english and will leave you alone  When in the MRT system you have to buy another pass (this time a black coin that is used the same way as the BTS system  Don't lose the coin as you need it for exit  The system was quite quiet both days we used it to get to and from Hua Lampong  After getting off it is a fair underground walk  You arrive at a 19th century train station that still has the commodities of 20th century

reviewTitle: Great support and connected to BTS
reviewText: Great way to move around Bangkok without hassle cheaper faster in  connected mass transit system for shop hopping food and seeing life and avoid horrendous traffic jams that happens out of no where
Great to get from one point to another in BKK Avoid taking it during rush hour (57pm) and you are bound to either go through a very tight squeeze since the train will be full or wait for a long time
bit daunting to try at first but easy to understand and could save time by skipping the famous Bangkok traffic

An excellent and fast way to get around Bangkok Tickets are inexpensive and several stations are located near shopping centres Are crowded in peak hours but that is the same in all major capital cities
alternative to the BTS this is operated by a different company this line is underground and uses a different card compared to the BTS   you can hop onto the mrt from hua lampong train station
I use MRT nearly every day as a resident in Bankkok As a pensionist you get half price Just ask for "elder ticket" at the ticket counter
An efficient and easy to use way around Bangkok Had no problems at all and can connect to Skytrain and Airports easily

I always take the MRT or bangkok metro to Chinatown (Hua Lamphong station) Terminal 21 (Sukhumvit station) Chatuchak or JJ market (Kampheng Phet station) whenever I visit Bangkok as it is fast reliable and convenient No more tuk tuk or meteredtaxi bringing you to Diamond Factory before reaching your destination or overcharging you when the shopping mall is near closing time   However during my visit last week I was disappointed with MRT unlike BTS as it is no longer protourism by stopping to sell the day pass So be prepared to buy the top  up MRT card for THB18000 with THB10000 value THB5000 refundable deposit and THB3000 nonrefundable card fee The validity of the card is two years No rebate or discount for using the card at all if you are an adult For school children also same price but enjoy a 10% discount on the fare
if you want to avoid traffic and travel cheap (atleast than in taxi) MRT is a good option Since I am used to using metro in Delhi I loved it took one from Chatuchak market

MRT network in Bangkok is quite impressive and convenient People are really cooperative I used it for two to three times while in Bangkok and every time I found it convenient and cheaper wrt other modes of transportationI wish there could be more self ticketing kiosk

reviewTitle: Excellent way to travel in Bangkok
reviewText: For the first few days I lived in a part of the city that wasn't serviced by the MRT or the BTS and Oh how much easier would it have been if it had  The MRT and BTS undoubtedly offer the best means of transportation in the city and I can only hope that it will be expanded as both are excellent services They are clean airconditioned fast and inexpensive
We used the MRT system for one trip just to say that we have been underground in Bangkok What we saw was a very clean and efficient method of transport
Connectivity is good with important places in bangkok and well organised  Cleanliness is appreciated

Quick clean and convenient way to get around Bangkok Trains every few minutes during peak times when it can be crowded Easy to interchange with SRT Airport Rail Link and BTS Can get tickets from either a machine or ticket window

even for visitors who don't know how to  buy ticket by the machine we still have ticket rooms in every station all the staff can speak English at least high speed not too crowd the radio will tell what is the next stop easy to connect with others public transports

Very convenient Depending on where you want to go it's common sense to choose a hotel close to the MRT or BTS Haggling price with tuktuk drivers is not my cup of tea specially with the language barrier

reviewTitle: Always a good way to travel around.
reviewText: The MRT was a crisp clean and efficient way of travelling around during my recent trip I could effectively plan visits all over Bangkok as a result

The MRT and BTS undoubtedly offer the best means of transportation in the city  Of course they can be quite congested at high travel times but people tend to be mindful and respectful to others  They are clean airconditioned and inexpensive

reviewTitle: State of the art subway system
reviewText: Clean efficient user friendly and fast The MRT along with Skytrain has revolutionized travel in Bangkok and provided a standard other traffic clogged cities should emulate However here's the problem They didn't integrate the MRT with Skytrain So two totally independent mass transit systems in the same dense city using two different ticketing systems Plus if you want to head into the emerging delights of Chinatown or the vast territiories surrounding the Grand Palace you're still on your feet or have to persuade reluctant taxi drivers to brave the traffic over there

While the MRT does not cover the entire city it remains among the best that i have ridden on It is efficient clean fast and inexpensive Its users are mindful of others civic minded and i have yet to come across misbehaviour eating or drinking while riding I believe it is the best transport system when you need to teavel given Bangkoks gridlocked roads
The MRT is an excellent way to travel around Bangkok Trains are new and well managed The price is also cheap Unfortunately it does not serve the old city area

Quick and easy way to get around Not to mention escape from the heat and humidity Like all transport systems world wide it gets pretty crowded during peak times  Great to use on it's own or in conjunction with the BTS (Skytrain) via the interchange stations Even if you just miss one train the next one never seems to be more than just a few minutes away  Also ticket machines accept notes up to 100 baht unlike BTS which is coin only And saves hassles with taxi's who don't want to turn the meter on

The MRT is pretty easy to navigate There are people working there that are helpful if you need to ask questions If you planning on going or taking the mrt during rush hours at night time be prepared to wake for couple of trains before you can get in It is packed with folks going home from work

I recently had to start riding the MRT for certain people I had to meet Very clean on time schedule I don‚Äôt ride everyday so the cost has been minimal Quiet ridenice addition to the transportation services in Bangkok
Amazing addition to BKK makes transport around the city very easy and accessible Things like this make BKK world class Emmaculate clean better than London etc

A very fast way to get around The stations are air conditioned and provide relief from the heat Great to get to where you want to go and good when used in conjunction with BTS at interchange stations For example we went from Silom to terminal 21 in 12 minutes then took a 2 minute BTS ride to Nana too easy
Best way to travel in Bangkok Fast easy cool and cheap They are building more lines and stations so in the future it will be nice to go to downtown by MRT Looking forward to that
Same as the skytrain except this on going underground Use the MRT if you're going to Chatuchak market as they have a station at this market
The MRT is very easy to use extremely clean and very helpful staff Such a great way to avoid the congestion and the road noise

reviewTitle: Great way to get around without traffic worries.
reviewText: After using a taxi to get to the new IKEA store at Bang Yai near Nonthaburi from Ari area we decided to use the MRT to return This is the purple line and it looks as though they are just about to open some new stations past Bang Yai Modern and clean service and can link to the BTS at Mor Chit near Jatujak weekend market Beats sitting in traffic anytime
We used the Bangkok MRT several times and found it to be an easy inexpensive and efficirnt way to get around town  It doesn't go everywhere in town but it's always easy to pick up a tuk tuk or cab
To a first time traveller it was easy to use the trains were on time and low cost fares  It is a subway so if you want to see the sights take the Skytrain

The MRT is a wonderful way to travel from A to B This underground train can only take you two ways so it is easy to find your way Having bought our tickets at the ticket office we descended the escalator to the platform There was only a short wait for the train which took us into the centre of Bangkok This service links with the BTS The station and the train were very clean and when we travelled at midday it was very quiet  Just another part of the excellent public transport system in Bangkok

reviewTitle: Great if you have no luggage.
reviewText: The MRT is the best way to get around BKK  However it you have luggage it can be a challenge    I now get a taxi to Makkasan instead of the MRT to get to the airport  If you have little or no luggage then it is the best way to travel fairly clean cheap and fast
The network is limited and it would appear to me Thai's are not keen on underground travel as the trains are not over full However if you can go by MRT it is batter than the skytrain

Another good alternatives to expensive taxi haggling and horrible traffic during peak hours Clean and cheap boarden the coverage of BTS and made more places easy to reach (The New Rot Fai Market Ratchada is reachable by MRT 3 stations away from Terminal 21Sukhumvit station where it used to be only reachable by taxi)  Just one thing BTS and MRT are not using the same card If you are go by ala carte you need to queue on a long line to purchase ticket if you are transiting at BTS Asok station to MRT Sukhumvit If you are using the Rabbit store value card this card is only usable at BTS but not MRT With the Rabbit card you still need to queue for MRT ticket Not sure if this is only for temporary but this is kinda below expectation

reviewTitle: Excellent way to get about BKK
reviewText: Cheap cool and efficent  why would you bother catching a taxi when BKK has the MRT  The kids enjoyed the ride and rated it better than the Tube in London or the rail system in Rome
Clean and efficient  Driverless trains every few minutes Just wish there were more areas covered hopefully this will happen soon
A good way to get around BKK Cheap elders buy a 50% discount card efficient clean and cool Interacts with the BTS at some stations covering a great deal of BKK The best way around the city

reviewTitle: One of the best ways to get around.
reviewText: The MRT is one of the best ways to get around in Bangkok There is a app that you can use that uses the MRT and the BTS Skytrain together Just put in your location then your destination and it give you the easiest and quickest way to get where you want to go
Best way to get around Thailand  I highly recommend spending some time to figure out and then it will save you time and money from taking a taxi or Tuk Tuk on the conjested Bangkok roads

The bangkok MRT is a few years old but you would have thought this opened yesterday Its very clean from the stations to the trains themselves We took a train from Silom to sukhumvit and was so cheap and took 10 minutes only Too busy at 6pm with the locals going home but thats everywhere in the world

MRT underground is a convenient way to travel around the new part of the city Being mostly underground it's cool as well But again as my gripe goes with Bangkok transports the network is just not sufficient to cover all parts of attractions

Buy a card and put the amount on it you want to save time and money The card will calculate how much you are spending The met is very organized Barriers are placed in front of the track so it is also very safe AC but seems warm with all the people

reviewTitle: Best mode of transport in a always traffic jam bangkok.
reviewText: Best mode of transport in a always traffic jam bangkok  All underground station  The weather in April Meaybe even year round is like a sauna Even evening the air is hot air  The traffic jam is the worse Worse than Malaysia KL and Singapore Best to take BTS or MRT

East to get around the main areas of Bangkok with the MRT Very reasonable fares alsobut very crowded during peak times and near closing time You can get to most of the attractions form here at all stops along the way
Found the mrt easy to use and a must form of transport in Bangkok like the skytrain also easy to use and so cheap compared to british forms of transport
Between this and the sky train it should make your life easy to around most of the city high lights this system might not be perfect yet but they are trying to improve it
MRT on covers certain parts of the city but comBined with the BTS river boats and the one rapid bus line you can beat the traffic It is also a good place to escape the heat
The MRT is the best way to get around Bangkok its cheap and time saving Quicker than a cab as the traffic is dreadful in Bangkok anytime of the day

reviewTitle: This is a fast, safe, clean way to travel
reviewText: Being from America I was expecting this to be horrible like our subways but it's really great  Everything is very clean and the people are not pushy or weird (though occasionally some old Chinese woman will probably yell out something obnoxiously loud)  Try it

The MRT is the subway system in Bangkok and is primarily used by the locals  As a subway it doesn't offer pretty views like the BTS Skytrain but it is slightly less expensive and will take you to areas not served by the BTS  Your "ticket" is a little plastic coin  hang onto it as you'll need it to get off at your destination  The stations seem to be unnecessarily large and occasionally difficult to navigate but most signage is in thai and English  Not quite as clean as the BTS but a fast easy way to get from place to place in Bangkok without having to hire a taxi  There are a couple of stations along the routes that allow easy transfer between the MRT and the BTS  the combination of the two particularly in conjunction with the river taxis allows you to get just about anywhere you'd need to go
A easy and cheap way to get around bangkok Ticket is not super expensive If you are close by it's faster than car during rush hour
Riding the MRT was fun  System uses smart cards and is an economical way to get around  System maps are easy to read and staff at the kiosks are friendly and helpful

reviewTitle: Bangkok Subway - Air Conditioned, Inexpensive and Fast Way to Get Around the City
reviewText: MRT is Bangkok‚Äôs subway system and is an air conditioned fast safe clean and inexpensive way to get around the city it has two lines to cover different ends of Bangkok blue line and purple line  Bangkok also has a skytrain system called the BTS (made up of two lines also the Sukhumvit and Silom lines) also air conditioned fast clean safe and inexpensive way to get around the city  Both systems have maps at the stations good signage (including English) and well marked stops  There are a couple of interchange stations (Silom and Sukhumvit MRT stations) where you can transfer from the MRT to the BTS (and vice versa) to fast track you to your destination   Bangkok is such a heavily traffic congested city so the MRT and BTS are excellent transportation alternatives to quickly get around the city and avoid sitting in traffic jams  Don‚Äôt shy away from using the MRT and the BTS to get around Bangkok just because you‚Äôre a visitor  Comparable to the well know similar type lines in Canada Europe and Japan   Traveller tip no open food or drink allowed on the train and be prepared to have your bag backpack or luggage quickly inspected at the turnstyle Be polite about it it‚Äôs for your own safety Bangkok takes security seriously and I‚Äôm happy that they do   For payment you can use a ticket machine or see the teller and for a prepaid card (you choose the amount to load onto card) With a ticket you slide it in the slot at the turnstyle and it pops in and back out (you‚Äôll need it at the exit gate same process) With the prepaid card all you do is swipe at the turnstyle in and again when you exit This is how the line knows how much to charge Some trips just a stop or two are as inexpensive as 26 baht  My husband and I are both currently living in Bangkok and we both use the MRT and BTS daily as our primary form of transportation  I highly recommend using the MRT and BTS to get around Bangkok

reviewTitle: May need to queue up for a long time to get ticket at Asok
reviewText: Since Rabbit card cannot be used for MRT if you have to get ticket at Asok (connected to BTS) there is always a long queue And return tickets are not available

reviewTitle: Great way to go around Bangkok
reviewText: Should travel out of rush hours It was easy to go around as it one straight line It take quicker than BTS and more comfortable

reviewTitle: Fast efficient urban transport in Bangkok
reviewText: The differences between MRT (underground) and BTS (SkyTrain) are mainly that one gives you views over the city whilst the platforms are open air and hot in warm weather whilst MRT gives you no cityscapes as it's underground but all the stations are very large and spacious and airconditioned  I'd say use BST in good weather and MRT in hot weather The 2 systems have meeting points and this system is extended now across the river  Avoid this system for joining the Airport Link at Makasan because there are loads of stairs to climb if you have heavy luggage There is an elevator but still

One of the best ways to get around Bangkok Fast cheap and air con Especially if you need to be at the Hua Lamphong station Only down part is that there aren‚Äôt any travel cards you can use on all Bangkok public transport systems

reviewTitle: The best asset in public transport.
reviewText: Most efficient in running times and there are security guards on each platform station They are clean run smoothly and above all comfortable All trains are air conditioned and the best way to get across Bangkok is by this public train During the rush hours  it can be crowded but nothing as bad as London However  having air conditioning does help tremendously
The MRT is simply the fastest way to get across this amazing city the carriages are clean well lit and air conditioned Gets a little crowded as you might expect during rush hours

reviewTitle: Just as easy and safe as the Skytrain!
reviewText: After several trips to Bangkok I finally tried the MRT  I have been a big fan and user of the Skytrain over the years given the traffic issues  I was worried about a dark and unsafe subway adventure but true to Thailand's culture the MRT was very clean efficient and extremely safe  For first timers I suggest you google some videos that show you how to buy tickets  Overall it runs just like the Skytrain with regards to the transit maps and boarding process  I do suggest you bring some coins or the smallest bills to use in the auto ticket machine otherwise you'll get a lot of coins as change  Another tip is that unless you have a multiple use card you be issued a plastic "coin" to use on each paid trip as your ticket The ticket machine will give you this coin  You don't deposit the coin in the exit gate until after you trip concludes  When first entering you tap the coin on the machine reader and the gate opens  This wasn't explained well on the videos I saw  Happy Travels

As good as any in developed country Great way to travel around Bangkok CBD especially  Sukhumvit area Best to avoid peak hours in the morning & evenings when it is packed with workers going about their routine Limited seating to provide more rooms for passengers So be prepared to stand and if no mobile best not to travel on it While there are seatings designated for passengers with disabilities or elderly is is more often ignored than honoured Passengers on these seats will just focused on playing their mobile devices or simply ignore those requiring a seat more then them

The best and cheapest way from Makasan to Hua Lamphong I think After we bought the tickets the security staff run to follow us to ask us again about the place where we wanted to go When he knew that we were in front of the right gate he nodded and smile It's very kind of him He gave us good first impression about Thailand  (March 2018)

reviewTitle: The best way to get around some parts of Bangkok
reviewText: We visit Bangkok almost every month leaving our private car at home and depending on public transport  The MRT is terrific  Clean efficient inexpensive and convenient though it can get very crowed during the rush hours of 08000930 11301330 and 16301900  that still leaves some time to travel around much the city in comfort  Not a very good way to travel with suitcases especially large and heavy ones that need to be lugged up stairs and inconvenience other travelers  If you are staying for more than a few days or are a frequent visitor it is best to purchase a travel card that can be updated when needed this saves time by facilitating the ticket process
MRT can be very busy at rush hour but still the cheapest and easiest and fastest way to get around the city
Budget friendly mode of travel within bangkok If connected to airport it would have been good Also travel timings need to be there till late night and early morning
BKK traffic is a nightmare and this service is great It doesnt' go everywhere but it is cheap fast and comfortable
We didn't travel far on the MRT it was part of a days tour but we found it easy to follow the route it was quick clean quiet and comfortable
They MRT was a great way to move around BKK  The traffic in BKK is terrible and the MRT is easy to navigate and very cheap  Once you learn your way around it is a great system to use
long distance take long time short distance much better went to soi 65 and its very long way and change was in silom road

We used the MRT service a couple of times whilst on a short weekend break in Bangkok The station was near our hotel and easily recognisable Maps and signage was clear and it wasn‚Äôt too hard to figure out how to get tickets and where to go etc The prices were very reasonable (approx 20 bhat  50p for a single journey) The trains are clean well maintained and air conditioned Regular daytime services  Shame there are not more stations in the tourist areas of the city as the MRT system is a quick cheap and easy way of navigating around Bangkok

We found the MRT to be fairly expensive as compared to our experiences of similar transport systems in other parts of the world Also the train frequency was not very frequent and the last trains (on weekdays) are scheduled at what we thought were not very late hours  However if you are traveling during the day and do not need to change lines it will be an effective way to travel

Very efficient rail network good pricingcars are nicely airconditioned and stations announced each stop only downfall is that if you need to change lines you need to go to siam to changemaybe that will be rectified one day Tip for travellers if you are going to be on the train a bit then get a day pass for 140 Bahtno need to scramble for coins during the day
should run more frequently for the size of the city  also no seating areas for old  tired  handicaped people

reviewTitle: It is modernized Mass Transit System but the routing is not covering throughout the overall city position.
reviewText: It is comfortable such as Singapore MRT and Hongkong MTR but its routing coverage need to be enlarged in order to cover the whole city

Similar to the BTS as a choice transportation mode   However the payment system for MRT and BTS is different resulting In super long queues just to get your token for the ride   If one payment system is used it‚Äôll be perfect Trains also take some time to arrive and usually between 58 mins
No tourist pass cardnot enough line Too crowd and long waiting time is Not so clean but no any alternative

reviewTitle: Beat the ridicules traffic in Bangkok
reviewText: Clean and like new also has some aircon at the stations unlike the BTS stations  people behave decently  unlike the trains and subways in the USA

reviewTitle: the best way to get around in bangkok
reviewText: Beat the traffic and take the MRT My advice would be to bring some coins up to 45 baht per person to buy your tickets as the lines to get coins for the ticket machines can be quite long

It's embarrassing coming from England seeing how other countries run their underground systems  Everywhere is spotlessly clean the trains are quick and everyone knows how to queue sensibly and politely

If you want to save some time while traveling around Bangkok Use MRT It's affordable and quick way to move around Bangkok City Unless you need excitement of Tuk Tuk and ready to pay what they ask for (if you cannot bargain with them) MRT is the easiest way to go Go to nearest MRT station and look their map Plan your trip where to go and jump into MRT Easy as breeze Enjoy your traveling around Bangkok and certain times full MRT's
We usually take the MRT when we were in Bangkok to avoid traffic congestions during peak hours It could be a headache to be stuck on the road

reviewTitle: Super easy and Convenient to use
reviewText: MRT combined with BTS will take care of much of your travel needs except Khao San road area MRT is very easy to use and clean and organized I highly recommend using it if it near the locations you need to go

I always use BTS in Bangkok  Best quickest and cheapest way to get around line gradually expanding keeping people out of traffic below    Stored value card very handy   Recommend choosing hotel within few minutes walk of a BTS station  Dedicated line now going out to Airport and links up with main line
Takes youlinks you anywhere you want to go  Just so easy but you have to get used to consulting the rail map and the names of the entrance ramps so you don't take the wrong train
A modern Mass Transit System  Fast and easy to use I would def use during rush hours If there is one issue its very cold inside the cars

I had trip in Bangkok and this MRT for my route this is smart way and short cut of the time for Bangkok transit there is station connect with BTS & Airport Link this way could help you for smart transit during Bangkok time Forget rush hours 56pm daily with Bangkok traffic jam if use car option

reviewTitle: Don't get on during rush hours!
reviewText: Thailand should be well known to its visitors for the horrible traffic no matter where it may be The roads the trains even in restaurants I have lived here for many years and although the trains have been installed a great alternative to travelling in the city of Bangkok (it's hasn't extended much out of the city center) and not get ripped off The subway does go to places that the BTS can't take you it is clean and pretty cheap The stations are huge but it gets really crowded in the morning around 7am10am from the Bang Sue  Hua Lamphong line and again around 7pm9pm from HuaLamphong  Bang Sue

reviewTitle: Limited network but does its job
reviewText: The MRT has only a limited network but does its job adequately  Stations are spacious and generally clean  Limited ticket vending machines but has English language option and easy to use  Useful to take MRT wherever possible

reviewTitle: Efficient, air conditioned, extremely friendly and helpful staff.
reviewText: We used the train during the weekend to travel from Hua Lamphong station to the Chatuchak Weekend Market and the JJ Greens Night Market  The ride cost TBH42 per person and the train was clean air conditioned and as fast as they come The staff were happy to help unsure tourists and the markets were a delight Highly recommended
The MRT (Metro subway) is an excellent alternative to get around in conjunction with the Skytrain and public bus system  Clean efficient fast and well maintained

This is just as easy as the BTS and just as cheap You select destination on self serve ticketing device and pay in baht Can range anywhere from 1570 baht depending how far you go Way cheaper and nicer than a taxi You don‚Äôt have to worry about being ripped off
A quick way to get around town but in peak hours you may need to wait for the fourth or fifth train before you can get on board  especially at stations such as Asoke

It's fast It's cheap It's really crowded The worst part is that it has limited range in the city It's great for downtown but even getting to the old city or Chinatownthe best it can do is come within a tucktuck ride

reviewTitle: Smart and better way to see Bangkok
reviewText: MRT is smart and better way to see Bangkok at affordable prices Cover parts of Bangkok city tourists and locals efficiently use this trains Fares for Single Journey Ticket varies between 16  41 Baht depending on number of zones crossed For tourist with Day Pass it cost you 120 baht for unlimited travels in one day Otherwise you can use several types of MRT Smart Cards Not like BTS Sky Train travelling at high position unfortunately the MRT routes are underground routes and passengers see nothing along the waysTwo routes are available Blue Line and Purple Line Combine this BTS with MRT train services will expand your transport coverage of Bangkok city significantly One of the good thing about MRT is one of the end station is Hua Lamphong close to the main station of long distance trains with the same name
A station that you can switch from BTS(skytrain)and MRT(subway)or vice versaVery popular and busy placebut you can pretty find pretty much anything (foodshoppingbars)

reviewTitle: Just what you'd expect from an old subway
reviewText: We took the MRT to Chinatown and found it just like most old subway systems dirty but it gets you where you want to go

The Purple line is the most useful for visitors as it connects with State Railways of Thailand's commuter and long distance trains to destinations such as Chiang Mai and Surat Thani  Underground trains are reliable smooth and frequent although during the off peak the latter drops off a bit  Ticketing has a day pass available but it does not seem to offer unlimited trips  Ticketing would improve if a multi modal ticket covering BTS and MRT was introduced  Staff are efficient and speak English a necessity given so many foreigners who use the MRT  Stations have lifts although there are a few steps from street level to negotiate so it is not completely disabled friendly  There are retail outlets at some stations  Trains as expected are crowded during the peaks

There are two main transportation systems in Bangkok other than taxis and busses  The BTS Skytrain like the name implies above ground and the MRT which is the subway  The MRT is by far hands down the more efficient and better managed company of the two  Unfortunately for tourists the BTS takes you thru the center of the city  The MRT circles around from Hua Lampong train station to Chatujack weekend market   MRT offers monthly passes senior and student tickets  No senior tickets at BTS  The MRT has escalators from train platform to ticket counter to street  The BTS was just forced to put in elevators and some stations do not have them at all  The MRT will be your best option if it takes you close to where you need to be ex work or school  It also brings you close to Thailand Cultural Center and right to the door of the Queen Sirikit Convention Center  Plan on very cold air conditioned trains

reviewTitle: A fast way around the city
reviewText: Fast cool (almost cold) airconditioned transportation around Bangkok It is now very busy since it has proven to be an efficient dependable means of travelling and the older Thais have gotten over their fear of ghosts in the underground

I use the MRT quite a bit  I wish mass transit had much more of a reach in and around Bangkok  The MRT and BTS are pretty new to Bangkok  The MRT is clean efficient and a very comfortable way to get around Bangkok  Thees no traffic jams on the tracks

I use the blue line quite often and am quite impressed with the cleanliness punctuality courtesy and helpfulness of station staff facilities at each station and overall value Ticket machines are plentiful and very user friendly Trains are properly temperature controlled as are stations Signage is excellent and several stations have modern minimalls with coffee shops convenience stores banking facilities takeaway restaurants etc Even when crowded it is a pleasure to ride the MRT (I‚Äôm originally from New York and this transport system puts the NYC Subway system to shame)
It is a very reliable & convenient mode of transport   It is cheap & easy to follow the tariffs  Good alternative to taxi & limo  Comfortable to travel with a toddler

reviewTitle: Using the subway in Bangkok was great!
reviewText: Anyone who thinks the United States has it all ought to look at Bangkok  The subway (MRT) is clean and good looking  New York's looks like a rathole compared to Bangkok  Tourists should not be afraid to use this or the skytrain

reviewTitle: Easy to use and very clean
reviewText: The Bangkok subway is a clean and efficient system of transportation  At the time of this review the stops favor commuters more than tourists so keep that in mind depending on the location where you stay in Bangkok  Future plans we were told would extend that line toward and under the river and some key tourist locations which will be very useful  We were impressed with the subway its ease of use cleanliness and timely trains

reviewTitle: Depends on where you're staying and where you're going
reviewText: The most ridiculous part of Bangkok public transit is how none of the services are integrated with each other BTS MRT bus riverboat express airport rail  all of these services require their own tickettokenfare Because of that it's a bit of a hassle to get from one part of town to another if you have to take more than one line   If you only need to use the MRT it's an easy to use service that's fast and efficient
Do yourself a favour avoid the taxi drivers who surprisingly of all the Asian countries we have been to will try to rip you off the most and get the BTS is you can
Using it from chatuchak market to sukhumvit Always busy  crowded But they have child  senior ticket price not like BTS

The MRT seemed like the older more reliable way to get further places through out Bangkok that were not just in the center It was easy enough to use and cheap You have to get tokens from the agents and when I looked lost it seemed that someone was always around who just happened to speak English After my first couple of times I felt most comfortable as it would get me where I needed to be without traffic outside pollution or wasting hours getting there You can check the internet before mapping out your destination take a few notes and GO

By far the cheapest and easiest way to get around Bangkok is to use the MRT Get a map and learn how to use it Even if the place you want is not next to an MRT stop you can then catch a taxi to where you want to go  quicker and cheaper The trains are airconditioned and the system is fairly easy to learn  most signs are in English and Thai and many staff speak a little English

reviewTitle: Cheap and easy method of transport
reviewText: Most of the machines accept notes but only give change in coins It's easy to get a token from the machines and if not just ask at the counter Outside of peak hour the MRT is simple to use and get where you need

The MRT is an efficient way to get around Bangkok It is important to do your homework and check out the MRT website maps and maybe some Youtube videos to help you navigate the subway You will need to know which exits to use and where your stops need to be The ticket machines are easy to use as well as the customer kiosks are very helpful Bring your coins to save time

reviewTitle: best way to travel in the kind of traffic bkk roads have
reviewText: you must see the routes of MRT and where ever possible use this s to maximum as otherwise it can take hours to reach by road
The trains and subways of Bangkok are amazingly clean comfortable and reliable  They do offer day passes and this is an easy way to discover the layout of the city
Good range of goods an international food court on 6th floor We found that the location was convenient range of shops good can bargain a bit

reviewTitle: Excellent way to cross the city
reviewText: The MRT is a great way to get around and move across the city very fast I usually go from Thailand Cultural Centre on Rathcadapisek to either Chatuchak when I am visiting the market or Asok interchange (Sukumvit) or sometimes to Silom and all the journeys are quick efficient clean and comfortable  It drastically cuts the time it gets to move across town
An easy access within the city and liked An always a time saver in the traffic high Bangkok and could plan to be on time with the MRT usage than Taxis

reviewTitle: Perfect way to get around Bangkok
reviewText: One of the easiest and affordable means of transport around the city  Also on elf the cheapest  Signs and directions to navigate are easy to understand  Connects to downtown Bangkok and the other parts of the city  Makkassan metro is the connecting station for the airport city link rail line

Super clean and has several stops throughout city Like BTS couldn‚Äôt ask more out of a train in a city like Bangkok Must use if you want fast easy and cheap way around city Traffic is terrible Trust us
the MRT is very cleanand very organised cheapfast and very cool on a stinking hot dayand it goes to most areas of intrest

reviewTitle: I pity the fool that goes to Bangkok and don't take the MR.T!
reviewText: We took the MRT (the MrT as we called it) as much as we possibly could while in Bangkok because we loved it  It was almost impossibly clean incredibly efficient and the other riders were beyond polite and respectful  There is a glass wall between the waiting are and the tracks so there is zero safety concern there The maps are very easy to read even for someone who speaks no Thai at all and all of the automated ticket machines have a "switch to English" option so even getting started is super fast and easy The fares are based on how far you need to go so you don't end up paying a lot for one stop like on some other systems they dispense a little plastic token that you swipe over a sensor to get in and then insert into a slot at the end of your ride  We generally took it for a ride of about 9 stops and the average fare was between 3040 Baht My favourite part of taking the MrT (other than calling it the MrT) was the animated video they would play on the trains for riders which showed what to do and not to do while using the system It featured these adorable little sausage shaped people and never stopped being hilarious

Bangkok is famous for its traffic gem  The best way to get around town without delay is to take either MRT (subway) and BTS (skytrain)  Both are very clean and efficient  The ticket purchasing is simple  Very similar except MRT uses plastic coin and BTS uses paper tickets

MRT The total distance is 21 kilometers There are 18 underground stations and 1 elevation station starting from the front of Bangkok Railway Station (Hua Lamphong) to the east along Rama IV Road Through the three lush parks until the cut Ratchadaphisek Road Turn left to the north along Ratchadapisek Road In front of Queen Sirikit National Convention Center Asoke intersection Rama 9 junction Huay Kwang intersection RatchadaLat Phrao intersection turn left onto Lat Phrao road To the mouth of the intersection Ladprao Turn left into Phaholyothin Road Throughout the weekend Arrive at Bang Sue Station And change the level from the underground route at Bang Sue station It's an elevated route Before the end of the station The station is shared with the MRTA Line Chalongrat fair The station is redirected from the blue line to the purple line
it is a expereicne to travel in mrt in bangkok and very safe and conveinent looking at the traffic on the road and should always use

Use tokens for single use travel or purshase a stored valued card ticket office is open at most stations until late Card is 180baht with 100 baht of travel Top up each 100 baht When you finish with the card  redeem to get 50baht back plus your unused fare money very good time saver
Depending on the hour you use it some will have rush others will be ok I liked how punctual it was  and how easy to use

reviewTitle: a must for getting around Bangkok quickly
reviewText: Typical underground system that serves well different areas of bangkok and intersects with both BTS and Aiport Link Crowded at Rush Hour as to be expected
Easy and comfortable to travel around Bangkok also economic that taxis Make sure to have a map so you not lost ask the rail authorities for assistance

First time took the MRT in Bangkok Many people queuing at the machines to change coins for purchasing tickets Should have a better system on purchasing tickets that accept coins and notes with change and not to change coins then purchase the tickets  It is timeconsuming hence the queue is always long

reviewTitle: The Bangkok underground or something like that
reviewText: I have been living in Bangkok since 2004 and so has the MRI It opened just a few weeks before I arrive It has proven its worth over the years and helped reduce the traffic in Bangkok So this is all good and I can find nothing wrong with the service It is still a modern service and puts the New York subway to shame  The only problem I have consistently found is the station cooling is underpowered During rush hour waiting for the trains can get very hot because of the mass of people in the station generating all that body heat But with trains arriving every few minutes it is not a big problem except for people who are sensitive and can overheat quickly  Over all if you need to get across town with minimum hassle take the MRT or BTS

The MRT train nework interfaces with the BTS "skytrain" and the combination lets anyone get tofrom a vast number of places in Bangkok One simply gets a "ticket" (actually a little black round token) enters the MRT train and gets off wherever one wants  One word of advice Before going to any destination in Bangkok as a person a where you are going to tell you what is the nearest BTS or MRT station Then go to the MRT or BTS train station nearest you locate the destination train station get the ticket and simply go No fuss no stress
MRT in Bangkok Thailand is convenient to use to travel around the city The stations are nice to walk on and some stations have food street sellers around

reviewTitle: Overall good ride experience, can't say the same for the ticketing machine
reviewText: The train rides I had in bangkok weren't too noisy quite smooth (nonjerky) and the commuter flow was pretty smooth even during peak hour Train tickets can be bought from either the counter or the machines The machines aren't userfriendlystill backwards some only accept coins and you can only buy one ticket at a time When waiting for the ticket to be issued from the machine don't try to grab for it when it's still coming out cos if somehow you "obstruct" the incoming ticket the machine will swallow your ticket and not refund you the money

reviewTitle: Great way to zip through BKK
reviewText: We stayed at the Swissotel Concorde that was next to an MRT stop It was a great way to zip to the old city or out to the weekend market or to the Sumkumvit  area Cheap and easy with the one time purchase of the MRT smart card Just reload the card when you need to Very quiet rides very clean Rode it early mornings and late at night (*after 11pm when tuktuk by night tour ended) and no problems at stations or on the trains
I took the train from Hua Lamphong to Asok  It will be good if the local authority putting more signage
a safe and affordable system of traveling to get around bangkok most stations are walking distance from most central points
Nice cozy underground rail system which connects all the major tourist destinations like Chatuchak Market Sukhumvit Lumpini etc

Cheap and most easy convenient way of travelling around in bangkok Bangkok is notorious for its traffic  so what better way to beat it than the MRT Clean and lovely cool AC air The tickets are very easy to purchase from the vending machines or the teller
The system is very easy for the tourist to use Signs are clear and it is easy to obtain a card to ride the MRT Personnel are polite and helpful

reviewTitle: A great way to get around but not as good as BTS
reviewText: The MRT is an excellent way to get around Bangkok but prefer BTS if going to an area serviced by both

Although the MRT is limited in the place it gores to if you need to use it then it is cheaper than the BST and also very efficient also links to the BSt and is the best way to get to CAhtuchak and China town
The BTS the Metro (MRT) and the river and khlong commuter boats are all easy to use fast and cheap None of them get stuck in traffic either The staff are very helpful

Bangkok has got several types of public transportation  The main one is the BTS or Skytrain and the subway or MRT Both are very modern and very convenient  The main drawback is that both are managed independently and they do not connect

reviewTitle: Fast and convenient but signs for stations can be more bold
reviewText: For long distance worth the cost to avoid traffic for shorter distances and for a group of 3 or 4  taxi will work out cheaper
If you are over 65 you are entitled to ‚Äúelder‚Äù tickets (or card) which cost half the price of the normal tickets Ask at the counter

MRT is the Bangkok version of the underground or tube or metro It is reliable fast clean and the airconditioning system is keeping the air cool (but not extremely cool as it is the case of the BTS) making it a very pleasant travel experience

The MRT is an underground tube system that runs through the most important localities in Bangkok and suburbs The older blue line originates at Hua Lamphong station and terminated at Tao Poon The new Purple line also called the Chalong Ratchadam line originates at Tao Poon and terminates at Khlong Bang Phai currently and the rest of the line till Rat burana is yet to become operational The minimum adult ticket is 16 bahts with gradual increments depending upon the distance I found its more economical to travel longer distances The Metro Malls in some important stations offer a wide variety of basic shopping Seamless ticket booking between blue and purple lines exists however no seamless ticketing for BTS and Airport Rail Link exists although the changing stations between these do exist
If you avoid rush hour  when you might not get into the next couple of trains because of the amount of people trying to catch it  it is clean quick safe reliable but also very cold get a jacket
We arrived at Don Muang Airport and took the bus to Chatuchak From there it was fast cheap and easy to travel further to our hotel
Very nice experiance for travel by MRT in Bangkokvery well maintained and clean and perfectly on time Excelent way to travel in Bangkok
Much better more reliable than trying to find a taxi (with a driver that actually used the meter and spoke english) One of the best ways to get around the city

I took the MRT back into the city after I was done shopping at Chatuchak market It is also very conveniently located it's within a few steps from the market   The train was on time clean and very fast It took me about 17 minutes to get back to Bangkok from the market The taxi charged me 400 baht which I think is overpriced and the MRT costs 51 baht depending on the zone you're traveling to  Very practical
The MRT is pretty useful to travel around you reach much faster and the connectivity was useful for us as we stayed close to Terminal 21
Along with bts the best way to move around city of Bangkok Lines are expanding and more stations are being added to entire network Very crowded during morning and afternoon rush hours

The ticket systems is not integrated yet with bts rabbit card And using the ticket machine you can only purchase one ticket at a time so very trouble some if you want to buy for your group  it is 8 person for us Around two or three stations are interchange with bts station

reviewTitle: Good choice if your destination is in the route
reviewText: It is cheap and efficient method to travel in Bangkok However most of the tourist attractions and popular destinations are fall into BTS routes than MRT

reviewTitle: Good way to get around avoid Bangkok traffice
reviewText: We used the MRT as much as possible & overall easy to use the newer station have a nice screen setup to choose your destination & pay  Take the token tap on the way in & drop it in the slot on the way out  Recommend to try
MRT is cheaper than BTS but don't reach to my place T_T The queue time is longer than BTS Some stations are very big and looks empty and there are Metro Mall in some stations too

If ya are traveling to Sukhumvit and don't have a lot of luggage then a 40 Baht can take ya from the airport to Sukhumvit in about 30 mins and it is hardly busy or crowded There are 2 stations that ya can get off at to reach the Sukhumvit station depending on where ya are staying at sukhumvit

Great way to get around Bangkok although it stops running at midnight and is limited in the area it serves  The only problem is that there are never any seats (sometimes literallysome cars have no seats at all merely hanging straps) and it's hard to stand and get jostled

MRT is very convenient for travellers who go to Bangkok It allows to easily transit from a few popular places and the signs are easy enough to follow Buy a Rabbit card so you don't have to queue to buy a ticket each time

My hotel very near the MRT so very convenient and cheap too compare to tuk tuk and taxi Bangkok has 2 type of trains (MRT & BTS) MRT is using token to enter and BTS is using card to enter Similar in Singapore so quite convenient to go around Bangkok by train and even faster Not sure where to go pls approach the train officer and ask

Outstanding fast and inexpensive Very good in combination with Skytrain (BTS) Check the map and choose the nearest station buy oneday ticket and go Every station has helpful people Unfortunately you have to buy different tickets for MRT and BTS
1 of the economical and fastest way to explore bangkok cityand the purchasing of ticket via the vending machine is easier compares to BTS Interactive touchscreen and easy to navigate

While staying Sukhumvit we caught the MRT to Chatuchak and Cultural centre It was one of the cheapest modes of transport in Bangkok much faster than travelling by taxi and less crowded than the BTS We waited less than 5 mins before the train arrived  Unfortunately you do sacrifice the views though

reviewTitle: Get avoid the traffic jam in BKK get MRT
reviewText: I always take MRT more than taxi or bus to get avoid the traffic jam in Bangkok which make me feel less stress and reach the destination on time Although it costs a little bit expensive
The MRT is clean fast efficient and comfortably air conditioned a great way to get around in Bangkok
good transfer but a little bit expensive than Singapore MRT and people inside it were so noisy There was no ticket's machine there
The MRT trains are efficient when it comes to getting somewhere fast A great alternative to Bangkok taxi and traffic jams In was surprisingly few people using it when I travelled around 10am to 2 pm

reviewTitle: Best mode of travel around town
reviewText: From my favourite hotel in phaya thai it is a quick walk to the MRT stars and I can travel to all the malls  MBK the golf outlet station The trains are clean and prompt such a great way to get around

The MRT is easy to use and convenient as well with stations near places you want to go  The stations are clean and well lit with cameras and security  and you don't need to wait long for a train to comeMaybe 5 or 6 minutes during non rush hour  The booth attendants spoke a bit of English and were helpful to a foreigner and pointed me the right way  Signage is clear and good and there was no graffiti all over the place like in North America's systems  You can use the machines or the booth to pay and as well you can connect to the BTS from the MRT  Air conditioning works fine and ventilation was good

Crowded during rush hours pretty easy to manuevour  Only thing is that there are3 different train companieslines so at certain transfers u might hve to walk out without a shelter Get the rabbit card from the train
Good connection to many interesting places for a low price Don't get stressed by too many people joining you in one waggon Go to the weekend market with this train

Very convenient and fast moving Very stable and comfortable If you miss the train  don't worry  you need not wait very long and the next one will be here very fast I heard that there are toilets in the station but no
A cheap cool and efficient way to travel the city Nice and clean it is a great way escape the traffic crawl of the streets

reviewTitle: A perfect way to get where you need and avoid surface traffic
reviewText: The MRT is clean fast and you never wait longer than 5 Minutes for a train In a city like Bangkok where Traffic Jams are standard day and nite it is an elegant quick way to get around

Like the Sky Train the travel is cheap and runs efficiently with a nice polite queuing system in place We used the Sky Train more than the Metro but single journey tickets were cheap and great to take us to the places not quite reached by the Sky Train  Don‚Äôt bother with taxis unless you absolutely have to

Easy to access via MRT Can go to Chatuchak directly Convenient for elderly too Counter customer service is friendly and pretty tooüòÅ They can understand simple English   Thai people is very helpful don't worry to ask for help‚ù§Ô∏è  Welcome Thailand üåª

Buy your ticket at the station all signs are in Thai and English maps are easy to use I was amazed and in awe that the Thais are so polite that they queue to get onto the trains  really impressive The trains are crowded at rush hour but are cool and there is little jostling people respect each others space Please take your rucksack off but do hold onto it
With the SkyTrain you get a view but never mind the MRT clean and the stations big and airy and no gridlock underground
This is a great way to travel it's easy to get a tokencard for travel and it also links with the airport link rail which is a super easy and cheap way to get to BKK airport

reviewTitle: Catching up with Singapore and HongKong!!
reviewText: The MRT eventhough is a short line and not many lines operational yet it is a very convenient way to travel  The trains are very clean and the ride very smooth  The MRT interconnects with the SkyTrain and you can literally not get out in the hot sun with the walkway connecting Skytrain stations and MRT stations  Bangkok has done this very well  I don't think anyone needs to bother with Taxi Uber or Grab  The most convenient way is Skytrain and MRT and both are very cheap and very convenient
stations and trains are super clean fast and efficient easy to navigate  and you can pay as you go at each station  a much better system than many Ive used
easy and fast to take from places to places  no need to be catch in the Jam that save me the time wasted on the traffic jam
Easy way to transport and so convenient way as an visitor i would take city art map and go wherever i want always looking for easy transport no more hurdle on traveling
We took the train just for one station and was impressed by the metros The ticketing system is pretty straight forward and also the entrances and exists are well marked

reviewTitle: Love the MRT, quick, airconditioned & cheap
reviewText: Love the MRT quick airconditioned & cheap Much easier to travel around BKK rather than pesky taxi's sitting in traffic jams

reviewTitle: ok to avoid the traffic jam
reviewText: but crowded and no aircon available So it is a kind of sauna to travel with the MRT But over all ok

I had made a comment here  aboit the BTS of Bangkok saying that the absurd cold inside of the wagons was really crazy  but the underground (MRT) is even more frozen as air conditioned temperature   the stupidity of those responsible would be criminal denunciation (as they make people sick)

The MRT Skytrain and BTS offer the easiest and most comfortable ways of getting around Bangkok and avoiding the trafficThe system is modern with aircon and wifi on the trains and a good information and station announcement system We found local Bangkok people very helpful and whenever we were looking a little lost they would stop and ask if they could hep The link to Survanabhumi airport is open and the one to don Muang will open within the next 6 months

reviewTitle: great way to travel in BKK
reviewText: Pretty much clean and mostly reliable It connects with the BTS skytrain at Sukhumvit and Silom station By using the MRT and BTS is a pretty good way to roam the city  chaktuchak market  Stay away from the rush hour (before 8 am and around 6 pm)

reviewTitle: The best way to go around downtown Bangkok
reviewText: Bangkok is not big but traffic is so bad Sometime you stay still for 10  20 minutes this is crazy During rush hour even express way are PACKED  Cars move slowly like a turtle  may be worst than a turtle Then came crazy cars passing by on shoulder  I mean SHOULDER   It is very dangerous You travel 20 kilometers will take you more than an hour sometime 2 hours CRAZY  So MRT train is the best transportation for you  FAST & CHEAP Stay away from those Crazy Traffic  Crazy Drivers
Inexpensive clean and reliable Very best means of transpo Used it everyday to see the sites of BangkokReclining Buddha Chinatown and dining

A good way of reaching other parts of the city not covered by SkyTrain  The downside is that they have a separate ticket system so if you have a Rabbit Card for SkyTrain it cannot be used on MRT This could and should change in the future to make it easier for people to travel seamlessly around the city

The MRT has been underused for years but with a new extension that changing The underground is a great option if its going your way the problem is that with only 1 line it probably doesn't Its good for connecting Hualamphon Station Sukhumvit and Chatuchak and a few other places

reviewTitle: Cheap, aircon but very busy you never get a seat
reviewText: A good way to beat the traffic fast clean modern but you will never hope for a seat cheap too Idea for getting around Bangkok
Very convenient and linked to sky walk connection Not expensive Has wide options with stations at most places of interest A little crowded during peak hours

The subway system is easy to use even if one doesn't understand Thai  We used the ticket machines which all offer instructions in English and the route system and platforms are simple to figure out  The stations and platforms are noticeably clean and tidy and the riders are polite and lowkey  A great way to get around a very large city
buy a day ticket and the day is yours get down at any stop get out  shop eat and get in the train whole day
